Nerve

Distribution in Hand

Median nerve

Supplies the lateral 2 lumbricals, thenar muscles (except adductor pollicis), lateral 3 and a half digits (including tips of the index, middle, and half of the ring finger), dorsal aspects of the fingertips of the lateral 3 and a half digits

Ulnar nerve

Supplies the medial 1 and a half lumbricals, hypothenar muscles, adductor pollicis, deep head of the flexor pollicis brevis, dorsal and palmar aspects of the little finger, medial half of the ring finger, and the corresponding aspects of the fingertips

Radial nerve

Supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm, but no direct innervation to the intrinsic muscles of the hand (excluding the first dorsal interosseous)

Superficial branch of the radial nerve

Supplies the dorsal skin of the lateral 2 and a half digits (excluding the fingertips)

Dorsal branches of the ulnar nerve

Supplies the dorsal skin of the medial 1 and a half digits (including the fingertips)

questions.text: In the management of mastitis in a breastfeeding mother, what is the initial treatment approach?
questions.explanation:
Symptoms

Management

Breast pain and tenderness

Apply warm compresses before breastfeeding; ensure proper breastfeeding technique to ensure complete emptying of the breast; pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen as recommended

Breast redness and warmth

Continue breastfeeding frequently to promote milk flow and clear the infection; apply warm compresses to the affected area; ensure proper latch and positioning during breastfeeding

Breast engorgement

Breastfeed or pump frequently to relieve pressure and empty the breast; apply cold compresses after feeding to reduce swelling; avoid tight-fitting innerwear or clothing

Flu-like symptoms (fever, body aches)

Rest, stay hydrated, and get adequate nutrition; continue breastfeeding or pumping to clear the infection; seek medical advice for appropriate management and possible antibiotic therapy

Nipple pain or cracking

Ensure correct latch and positioning during breastfeeding; use lanolin or other nipple creams to soothe and promote healing; seek assistance from a lactation consultant if necessary

Presence of pus or abscess

Antibiotic therapy may be necessary to treat the infection; incision and drainage of abscess may be required in severe cases

questions.text: When is the optimal period to assess nuchal translucency?
questions.explanation:
Trimester

Ultrasound Examination

Timing (in Weeks)

Significance

First Trimester

Transvaginal Ultrasound

6-8 weeks

- Confirming pregnancy and gestational age- Assessing fetal viability - Detecting multiple pregnancies - Evaluating ectopic pregnancies or miscarriages
 

Nuchal Translucency Ultrasound

11-14 weeks

- Screening for chromosomal abnormalities, such as Down syndrome
 

Dating Ultrasound

8-12 weeks

- Determining precise gestational age- Assessing fetal growth

Second Trimester

Anatomy Scan (Level 2 Ultrasound)

18-20 weeks

- Assessing fetal anatomy and organ development - Detecting structural abnormalities
 

Fetal Biometry Ultrasound

Throughout the trimester

- Monitoring fetal growth and well-being - Assessing fetal size, including head circumference, abdominal circumference, and femur length

Third Trimester

Growth Ultrasound

Every 4-6 weeks from 28 weeks until birth

- Assessing fetal growth and weight - Monitoring amniotic fluid levels
 

Doppler Ultrasound

Throughout the trimester

- Assessing blood flow in the umbilical cord and fetal vessels - Monitoring placental function
 

BPP (Biophysical Profile) Ultrasound

Typically from 32 weeks until birth

- Assessing fetal well-being, including fetal movements, breathing, muscle tone, amniotic fluid volume, and heart rate
 

Presentation Scan

Around 36 weeks

- Determining fetal presentation (head-down or breech) in preparation for delivery
 

Position and Placenta Ultrasound

Throughout the trimester

- Assessing placental location and maturity - Checking for placenta previa or other placental abnormalities

questions.text: What is the most suitable treatment option for a pregnant woman who has a history of multiple miscarriages and has been recently diagnosed with antiphospholipid antibody syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Correct option B: Aspirin + H

Clinical Features

Management

Recurrent pregnancy loss

- Aspirin (60-80 mg/day)
 

- Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) starting before pregnancy and continuing throughout pregnancy
 

- Close monitoring of pregnancy with regular ultrasound and Doppler assessments
 

- Consideration of additional therapies, such as corticosteroids, intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)

Venous thromboembolism (DVT, PE)

- Anticoagulant therapy with LMWH or warfarin, depending on the individual case

Arterial thromboembolism (stroke, MI)

- Anticoagulant therapy with LMWH or warfarin, depending on the individual case

Thrombocytopenia

- Treatment guided by the severity and clinical context
 

- Consideration of corticosteroids or other immunosuppressive therapies

Other manifestations (e.g., livedo reticularis, neurological symptoms)

- Treatment based on the specific manifestations and severity
 

- Management may include anticoagulation, immunosuppressive therapy, and symptomatic treatment

questions.text: Which of the following acts as a physiological antidote to scorpion venom ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - P

Mechanism

Explanation

Scorpion Venom

Scorpion venom contains various neurotoxins that stimulate the sympathetic nervous system, leading to increased release of norepinephrine (a neurotransmitter) and subsequent activation of alpha-1 adrenergic receptors.

Prazosin

Prazosin is an alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonist, meaning it blocks the binding of norepinephrine to these receptors. By inhibiting the activation of alpha-1 adrenergic receptors, prazosin counteracts the vasoconstriction and other sympathetic responses caused by excessive sympathetic stimulation from scorpion venom.

Effect

The blockade of alpha-1 adrenergic receptors by prazosin results in vasodilation (relaxation of blood vessels), which helps to lower blood pressure.

Typical Value (in adults)

500 mL

Additional volume of air that can be exhaled after a normal tidal expiration

Residual Volume (RV)

Volume of air remaining in the lungs after maximal expiration

Maximum volume of air the lungs can hold, including inspiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, expiratory reserve volume, and residual volume

5,000-6,000 mL

Vital Capacity (VC)

Maximum volume of air that can be exhaled after a maximal inspiration, including inspiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, and expiratory reserve volume

4,500-5,000 mL

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC)

Volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal tidal expiration, including expiratory reserve volume and residual volume

2,400-2,800 mL

Inspiratory Capacity (IC)

Maximum volume of air that can be inhaled after a normal tidal expiration, including tidal volume and inspiratory reserve volume

3,500-3,800 mL

questions.text: What is the cause of the appearance observed in IVP?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option b: Ureterococele.

Definition Ureterocele is a congenital or acquired condition where the ureter (the tube that carries urine from the kidney to the bladder) balloons at its lower end, forming a pouch-like structure.
Types Primary (congenital) and secondary (acquired) ureteroceles. Primary ureteroceles are typically present from birth and occur as a result of abnormal embryonic development. Secondary ureteroceles may develop later in life due to various factors.
Location Most commonly found in the ureter that drains one kidney, but bilateral ureteroceles (affecting both kidneys) can occur in rare cases.
Presentation Ureteroceles can be asymptomatic or cause a range of symptoms, including urinary tract infections (UTIs), flank pain, abdominal discomfort, hematuria (blood in the urine), and difficulty in emptying the bladder.
Diagnosis Typically diagnosed through imaging studies such as ultrasound, intravenous pyelogram (IVP), CT scan, or cystoscopy.
Treatment Treatment depends on the severity of symptoms and complications. Options may include antibiotics for UTIs, surgical removal of the ureterocele, endoscopic procedures, and in some cases, surgery to reconstruct the urinary tract.

questions.explanation:
Intracranial Hemorrhage

Key Features

Epidural Hematoma
  • Typically caused by arterial bleeding
  • Lens-shaped blood collection between the skull and the dura mater
  • Associated with head trauma or skull fracture

Subdural Hematoma
  • Typically caused by venous bleeding
  • Blood collection between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater
  • Can be acute, subacute, or chronic

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
  • Bleeding into the subarachnoid space
  • Can result from ruptured aneurysms or head trauma
  • Often presents with a sudden severe headache
  • May be associated with neck stiffness or photophobia

Intracerebral Hemorrhage
  • Bleeding within the brain tissue itself
  • Can be caused by hypertension, trauma, or other underlying conditions
  • Symptoms depend on the location and extent of the bleed, such as weakness, numbness, or changes in consciousness

questions.text: The following images A and B show?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Jersey finger & baseball fing

Hand Injury

Explanation

Gamekeeper's Thumb

Injury to the ulnar collateral ligament (UCL) of the thumb, usually resulting from a forceful abduction or hyperextension of the thumb.

Mallet Finger

Injury to the extensor tendon of the finger, specifically at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. This injury is often caused by a forceful blow to the fingertip or by forcefully jamming the finger.

Jersey Finger

Injury to the flexor tendon of the finger, specifically at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. It occurs when the flexor tendon is torn or avulsed from its attachment to the bone, typically due to forceful extension of the finger while it is actively flexed, such as when trying to grab an opponent's jersey in sports.

Trigger Finger

A condition characterized by the inflammation and narrowing of the flexor tendon sheath in the finger.

Boxer's Fracture

A fracture of the metacarpal bone in the hand, specifically the neck of the metacarpal. It usually results from a direct impact with a closed fist, such as during a punch.

questions.text: Which of the following is an oral factor Xa inhibitor ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Riv

Type of Anticoagulant

Mechanism of Action

Vitamin K antagonists(e.g., warfarin)

Inhibit the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase, which is responsible for the conversion of vitamin K epoxide to its active form. This inhibits the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X.

Direct thrombin inhibitors(e.g., dabigatran)

Bind directly to thrombin (factor IIa), inhibiting its ability to convert fibrinogen to fibrin and preventing thrombus formation.

Factor Xa inhibitors(e.g., rivaroxaban, apixaban)

Inhibit the activity of factor Xa, which plays a key role in the coagulation cascade by converting prothrombin to thrombin. By inhibiting factor Xa, these drugs prevent the formation of fibrin and subsequent clot formation.

Heparins(e.g., unfractionated heparin, low molecular weight heparins)

Enhance the activity of antithrombin III, a natural inhibitor of clotting factors. This increases the inhibition of factors IIa (thrombin) and factor Xa, leading to decreased clotting activity.

Ventricular Arrhythmia

ECG Findings

Ventricular Tachycardia
  • Wide QRS complex (>0.12 seconds)
  • Absence of P waves or dissociated P waves
  • Regular or slightly irregular rhythm
  • Monomorphic (consistent QRS morphology) or polymorphic (varying QRS morphology)
  • Ventricular rate typically between 100-250 bpm

Ventricular Fibrillation
  • Chaotic and irregular rhythm
  • Rapid, irregular, and uncoordinated QRS complexes
  • Absence of identifiable P waves
  • Absence of clear T waves
  • "Quivering" or "fine to coarse" fibrillatory waves seen throughout the ECG

Annual Blood Examination Rate (ABER)

Percentage of the population at risk of malaria who have undergone blood examination for malaria parasites

Assesses the coverage and efficiency of the surveillance system in terms of diagnostic testing for malaria

Slide Positivity Rate (SPR)

Percentage of blood slides examined that test positive for malaria parasites

Provides information about the proportion of individuals tested who have confirmed malaria infection

Slide Falciparum Rate (SFR)

Percentage of blood slides examined that test positive for Plasmodium falciparum

Focuses on the prevalence of P. falciparum infection among tested individuals

questions.text: What is the main unit of administration in India called?
questions.explanation:
Principal Unit of Administration

Description

Village

Villages are the basic units of rural administration in India. Several villages together form a larger administrative unit known as a block or tehsil.

District

Districts are the principal units of administration in India.. Districts are further divided into smaller administrative units such as sub-districts (tehsils) or taluks, which comprise multiple villages.

State

States in India have their own elected governments and legislatures.. States consist of multiple districts, and each district has its own administration under the state government.

Centre

The Centre refers to the Central Government of India, which is the highest level of administration in the country. The Centre interacts with the states and provides guidance and support in various areas, but it does not directly administer local units.

questions.text: If a patient tests positive for a disease, which of the following represents the probability of her actually having the disease?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Positive predictive value (PPV)

Measure

Formula

Definition

Sensitivity

Sensitivity = TP / (TP + FN)

Sensitivity, also known as the true positive rate or recall, is the proportion of true positives (TP) correctly identified by a diagnostic test. It indicates the ability of the test to correctly identify individuals who have the disease or condition.

Specificity

Specificity = TN / (TN + FP)

Specificity is the proportion of true negatives (TN) correctly identified by a diagnostic test. It represents the ability of the test to correctly identify individuals who do not have the disease or condition.

Positive Predictive Value (PPV)

PPV = TP / (TP + FP)

PPV, also known as precision, is the proportion of true positives (TP) out of all positive test results (TP + FP). It represents the probability that a person has the disease or condition given a positive test result.

Negative Predictive Value (NPV)

NPV = TN / (TN + FN)

NPV is the proportion of true negatives (TN) out of all negative test results (TN + FN). It represents the probability that a person does not have the disease or condition given a negative test result.

questions.text: Which statistical diagram represents the population change in a specific location from 1983 to 1989?
questions.explanation:
Graphical Representation

Description

Line Graph

Displays data points connected by straight lines to show trends over time or continuous variables.

Bar Graph

Uses bars of equal width to represent categorical data or compare values across different categories.

Pie Chart

Represents parts of a whole using sectors of a circle, showing the proportion of each category.

Histogram

Displays the distribution of continuous or grouped data by using bars of varying heights to represent the frequency or relative frequency of data within specific ranges or bins.

Area Chart

Similar to a line graph but with the area under the line filled, used to represent accumulated totals or proportions over time.

  • High priority

  • Require immediate resuscitation or life-saving surgery.
  • E.g.- hemothorax or pneumothorax

Yellow or Blue
  • Medium priority
  • Victims must be helped within 6 to 24 hours but can wait up to 24 hours.

Green
  • Low priority
  • These victims are ambulatory and can move with minor injuries.

Black
  • Least priority
  • They are either dead or moribund (likely to die)
